articles.headline: Factory Explosion Follows Yemeni Forces’ Pullout
articles.snippet: Yemen’s political crisis deepened Monday when an explosion tore through a crowd of looters at an abandoned government weapons factory in the south, killing at least 110 people.
articles.abstract: Yemen’s political crisis deepened Monday when an explosion tore through a crowd of looters at an abandoned government weapons factory in the south, killing at least 110 people.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Yemen’s political crisis deepened Monday when an explosion tore through a crowd of looters at an abandoned government weapons factory in the south, killing at least 110 people and underscoring an ominous collapse of authority after six weeks of rising protests.
articles.byline: By Laura Kasinof and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: Japan’s Electricity Shortage to Last Months
articles.snippet: The term “rolling blackouts” has become shorthand for noting one way Japan is trying to cope with its national calamity. Shorthand should not be confused with short term.
articles.abstract: The term “rolling blackouts” has become shorthand for noting one way Japan is trying to cope with its national calamity. Shorthand should not be confused with short term.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The term “rolling blackouts” has become shorthand for noting one way Japan is trying to cope with its national calamity.

articles.headline: Food Inflation Kept Hidden in Tinier Bags
articles.snippet: In downturns, companies reduce the size of some products, disguising price increases and avoiding comparisons on same-size packages.
articles.abstract: In downturns, companies reduce the size of some products, disguising price increases and avoiding comparisons on same-size packages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chips are disappearing from bags, candy from boxes and vegetables from cans.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Catherine Rampell

articles.headline: Arriving as Pregnant Tourists, Leaving With American Babies
articles.snippet: Officials shut down a “maternity tourism” house in California where, they say, Chinese women paid tens of thousands of dollars to stay and deliver their babies, making the infants automatic American citizens.
articles.abstract: Officials shut down a “maternity tourism” house in California where, they say, Chinese women paid tens of thousands of dollars to stay and deliver their babies, making the infants automatic American citizens.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN GABRIEL, Calif. — The building inspectors and police officers walked into the small row of connected town houses here knowing something was amiss. Neighbors had complained about noise and a lot of pregnant women coming and going. And when they went into a kitchen they saw a row of clear bassinets holding several infants, with a woman acting as a nurse hovering over them.

articles.headline: Facebook Prepares to Add Friends in Washington
articles.snippet: Facebook is establishing a presence in the nation’s capital to defend itself on issues like privacy.
articles.abstract: Facebook is establishing a presence in the nation’s capital to defend itself on issues like privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook is hoping to do something better and faster than any other technology start-up-turned-Internet superpower.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Obama Cites Limits of U.S. Role in Libya
articles.snippet: President Obama defended the military assault in Libya, saying it was in America’s national interest to stop a potential massacre.
articles.abstract: President Obama defended the military assault in Libya, saying it was in America’s national interest to stop a potential massacre.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama defended the American-led military assault in Libya on Monday, saying it was in the national interest of the United States to stop a potential massacre that would have “stained the conscience of the world.”

articles.headline: Amber Waves to Ivory Bolls
articles.snippet: Many farmers, both in the United States and abroad, are expected to chase the higher profits to be made in cotton, with consequences that could ripple across the globe.
articles.abstract: Many farmers, both in the United States and abroad, are expected to chase the higher profits to be made in cotton, with consequences that could ripple across the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPEARMAN, Tex. — Tight supplies of corn, soybeans and wheat have sent prices skyrocketing in the last year, prompting worries of a looming global food crisis.

articles.headline: Regulators to Set Rules on Mortgage Securities
articles.snippet: Banks will be forced to retain a stake in most bundles of loans, except those that contain what a lawyer called “very old-fashioned mortgages.”
articles.abstract: Banks will be forced to retain a stake in most bundles of loans, except those that contain what a lawyer called “very old-fashioned mortgages.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Banks will be forced to retain some risk when they securitize all but the most conservative mortgages under rules that regulators are expected to vote on Tuesday. But the banks are likely to be given wide leeway in determining what risks to keep.

articles.headline: 3-Month Nightmare Emerges in Rape Inquiry
articles.snippet: Court documents and an exclusive interview with the father of an 11-year-old girl who the police say was the victim of repeated gang rapes in East Texas paint a grim portrait of an episode that lasted many months.
articles.abstract: Court documents and an exclusive interview with the father of an 11-year-old girl who the police say was the victim of repeated gang rapes in East Texas paint a grim portrait of an episode that lasted many months.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND, Tex. — A year ago, the 11-year-old girl who the police say was the victim of repeated gang rapes in this East Texas town was an outgoing honor roll student, brimming with enthusiasm, who went on hikes and planted trees with a youth group here.
articles.byline: By JAMES C. McKINLEY and ERICA GOODE

articles.headline: Allies Count on Defiant Streak in Libya to Drive Out Qaddafi
articles.snippet: Coalition forces are banking on a challenge to official authority from the people and tribes of western Libya to drive Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi from power.
articles.abstract: Coalition forces are banking on a challenge to official authority from the people and tribes of western Libya to drive Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi from power.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — The official government tour was supposed to show Western journalists the suffering of people who had been driven from their homes by the allied bombing in the city of Mizda, Libya. But the people themselves did not cooperate: when a half-dozen of them emerged from their tent encampment and fired rifle shots, the visitors were forced to beat a hasty retreat.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: Confidence Slips Away as Japan Battles Nuclear Peril
articles.snippet: The flow of bad news has undermined the drumbeat of optimistic statements by officials who have tried to reassure a nervous public that progress is at hand.
articles.abstract: The flow of bad news has undermined the drumbeat of optimistic statements by officials who have tried to reassure a nervous public that progress is at hand.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — After workers switched on the first set of control room lights at Japan’s crippled power plant in Fukushima last week, the Japanese government offered its strongest assurances yet that its nuclear crisis was close to being under control.
articles.byline: By Ken Belson and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: U.S. Housing Prices Fell Again in January
articles.snippet: A 1 percent decline left prices barely above the recession lows, indicating a still weak market.
articles.abstract: A 1 percent decline left prices barely above the recession lows, indicating a still weak market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The housing market remains mired in trouble, with plummeting prices and slumping sales. First-time buyers are fleeing, sellers are frustrated, builders are depressed and lenders are skittish about making new loans.
